newsitem.title: UK: ACPC to meet Jan 23 to consider coffee export plan.
newsitem.headline: ACPC to meet Jan 23 to consider coffee export plan.

text.p: Coffee exporters are to meet for an emergency session on January 23 to decide whether to reduce export quotas to stabilise the world market, an official of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) said on Monday.
ACPC secretary general Roberio Oliviera Silva said the meeting was scheduled to be held in Brazil, following an annual coffee seminar.

"We are going to analyse the market situation, assess the implementation of the export programme in the first six months and consider if it is necessary or not to change the export quotas," Silva told Reuters.
A plan put forward by Ivory Coast and Uganda has called for an additional cut of 2.5 million 60-kg bags in the first six months of 1997 on total exports of 53.5 million bags agreed by ACPC in May.
Brazil, the world's biggest exporter, has not expressed a view yet.
ACPC sources said the additional retention might not be proportional across ACPC member countries and could affect robusta mostly.

Silva said he had no doubt all members had observed the export limits set by the ACPC and this was reflected in the tight market situation for nearby supplies, but the meeting in Brazil would look at whether there is a demand-suppy imbalance in the robusta market.
"We have a great concern over the arbitrage between New York and London," he said.
